stream_context.summary: Kaze brainstorms and designs the multi-phase boss fight for Raphael the Raven in Course 13. He also models the initial boss arena tower, imports a new music track for the level, and discusses his game design philosophy.

development_findings.summary: A detailed, multi-phase boss fight for Raphael the Raven was designed, involving Mario being launched to a moon, dodging projectiles in a free-fall section, and using items spawned from the boss's attacks to deal damage.
development_findings.quote: Stomp sends Mario flying. You have to dodge stars until you land on the moon... Pick up the ninja star and throw it at him.

development_findings.summary: A 'hollow moon' boss fight concept was rejected due to technical constraints; Kaze prefers to implement features on an actor-level rather than making universal changes to the game engine's physics.
development_findings.quote: To do the hollow moon properly, we would need to make a change to how gravity works like universally, which I don't want.

development_findings.summary: Kaze plans to collaborate with fellow modder Arthur to implement planetary gravity for the boss fight, intending to use Arthur's pre-existing code.
The game's scope includes a large custom soundtrack of 98 songs, exceeding that of official titles like Super Mario Odyssey.
development_findings.quote: Right now we have, I think, 98 songs in the game... Compare that with Mario Odyssey. How many songs are in Mario Odyssey? 82 songs.

development_findings.summary: The game's music is implemented using two methods: a MIDI-like M64 format for ~80-90% of tracks and a large, resource-intensive streamed audio format for the remainder.
Kaze identifies a bug in the Fast64 toolset where using 'material bleeding' can cause fog to be incorrectly applied to geometry, affecting the visual output on N64 hardware.
The game is planned to have approximately 180 stars and 75 Yoshi Coins, with Kaze noting the collectibles are not a one-to-one comparison with games like Super Mario Odyssey.
The final star from the Raphael the Raven boss fight will spawn from an egg in a nest, which Kaze believes will create a cool narrative moment where the boss appears to be protecting it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes the core design philosophy of Mario 64 is player freedom, where difficulty is emergent from players choosing to take risks, rather than being imposed by the level design.
context_findings.quote: I am convinced people that need Mario 64 to be difficult just do not understand the point of Mario 64. The point is that you're free. It's all freedom. If you want the game to be more difficult and do more risky jumps, just go for it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze intentionally avoids looking at the Nintendo 'giga leak' content, fearing potential legal repercussions and unwanted creative influence from the leaked material.
context_findings.quote: I wanted nothing to do with that. Just because I think that even just knowing about things in the giga league can get you in trouble. It's like the curse knowledge.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses disdain for the 'money-driven' culture in the programming industry, believing it created an unsustainable bubble.
context_findings.quote: All I care about in this major is money... That's how people treat a programming for the longest time. And of course the bubble was going to burst.

context_findings.summary: Kaze mentions his newborn child (two weeks old) with his wife and collaborator, Zeina, providing context on his current personal life and work-life balance.
Kaze shares a personal anecdote about a family story he intends to pass down to his children, illustrating a personal connection to the Mario character.
context_findings.quote: I will tell my kids that their grandfather used to be Mario because my dad used to tell me that he used to be Mario before he became who he is right now.

biobak.summary: Biobak, the graphics artist, contributed a video concept for the Raphael the Raven boss fight, indicating his involvement in the game's conceptual design.
biobak.quote: Let me just see if I can find the video that bio back had sent me here a while ago... This is what he was thinking. That's so cool.

badub.summary: Kaze praises composer Badub's creativity while importing and implementing his music for the Course 13 Ice Dungeon.
badub.quote: Badubb's music is great. The creativity he brings to the table is very, very sick.

zeina.summary: Kaze mentions his wife and animator, Zeina, in the context of their two-week-old newborn, highlighting the intersection of their personal and professional lives.
zeina.quote: Of course, Zeina has a lot more work with it than I do. I guess I can't feed the baby, I do not have boobs.

key_stories.title: Designing the Raphael the Raven Boss Fight
key_stories.summary: Kaze designed the Raphael the Raven boss fight, moving from initial concepts to a final, unique multi-phase battle. He rejected a simple remake of the original fight and a technically complex 'hollow moon' idea in favor of a fight on a spherical moon using 'frozen cheese ninja stars' as projectiles.
key_stories.challenge: To design a unique and memorable 3D boss fight for Raphael the Raven that honors the original game but is not a simple copy and is technically feasible within the SM64 engine.
key_stories.process: Kaze brainstormed ideas, rejecting a direct copy of the original fight as 'lame' and a 'hollow moon' concept as too technically complex. He combined elements he liked—the moon setting, falling through space, and projectile attacks—to form a concrete plan.
key_stories.outcome: A detailed, multi-phase boss fight concept was fully mapped out, including an intro cutscene, a fight on a spherical moon with planetary gravity, and a unique 'frozen cheese ninja star' projectile mechanic.
key_stories.key_quote: Wouldn't it really be good to just recycle the exact same boss fight that Yoshi's Island has though? Isn't that kind of lame? Doesn't that feel like a cheap callback?

key_stories.title: Importing the Ice Dungeon Music
key_stories.summary: Kaze needed to import a new music track for Course 13. He demonstrated his process of finding the exact loop points by visually inspecting the waveform, calculating the sample numbers, and using his tools to implement the looping stereo track in the game.
key_stories.challenge: To correctly import a new stereo music track from composer Badub and ensure it loops seamlessly in-game, which requires finding the precise loop points.
key_stories.process: Kaze listened to the audio, visually identified the loop point by comparing waveforms in an editor, calculated the exact sample numbers for the loop's start and end, and updated the game's sound data before recompiling to test it in-game.
key_stories.outcome: The new music track for the Ice Dungeon was successfully imported with correct stereo channels and a seamless loop, ready for use in the level.
key_stories.key_quote: This looks almost identical, right? Am I insane? ... Okay. So I'm off by one beat. It should be like this. I think there we go.
